qas.question: What does this type of elevator use to propel the cage?

answers.text: a vacuum on top of the cab and a valve on the top of the "shaft"

qas.question: For sudden surges in pressure above the cab, what is used as a "brake"?
How does it enable the cab to go down by it's own weight?

answers.text: it opens the valve so that the air can pressurize the top of the "shaft"

qas.question: What is the shaft made of?
How much weight is permitted on a low capacity elevator?

context: A elevator of this kind uses <a0_0>a vacuum on top of the cab and a valve on the top of the "shaft"<a0_0/> to move the cab upwards and closes the valve in order to keep the cab at the same level. <a1_0>a diaphragm or a piston<a1_0/> is used as a "brake" if there's a sudden increase in pressure avove the cab. however, to go down, <a2_0>it opens the valve so that the air can pressurize the top of the "shaft"<a2_0/>, allowing the cab to go down by its own weight. this also means that in case of a power failure, the cab will automatically go down. the "shaft" is made of <a3_0>acrilic<a3_0/>, is always round, due to the shape of the vacuum pump turbine. in order to keep the air inside of the cab, rubber seals are used. due to technical limitations, these elevators have a low capacity. they usually allow 1-3 passengers and <a4_0>up to 525 lbs<a4_0/>.
